name: Phishing
description: Phishing is the fraudulent practice of sending emails purporting to be from reputable companies in order to induce individuals to reveal personal information, such as passwords and credit card numbers.
meta_description: Phishing is the fraudulent practice of sending emails purporting to be from reputable companies in order to induce individuals to reveal personal information, such as passwords and credit card numbers.
meta_keywords: Phishing, fraudulent practice,

name: Pentest Phases
description: Pentest Phases
meta_description: Pentest Phases - Different phases of a pen test. learn more at evilsaint.com
meta_keywords: Pentest phases,

name: BurpSuite Pro
description: BurpSuite Pro, application web proxy
meta_description: BurpSuite Pro, application web proxy. Read more at evilsaint.com
meta_keywords: BurpSuite, BurpSuite Pro,

name: Tools
description: Some of the most popular pentest tools
meta_description: Some of the most popular pentest tools, check out the most popular and commonly used pentest tools at evilsaint.com
meta_keywords: pentest tools,

name: External Remote Services
description: External Remote Services Contrary to popular belief, Lorem Ipsum is not simply random text. It has roots in a piece of classical Latin literature from 45 BC, making it over 2000 years old. Richard McClintock, a Latin professor at Hampden-Sydney College in Virginia, looked up one of the more obscure Latin words, consectetur, from a Lorem Ipsum passage, and going through the cites of the word in classical literature, discovered the undoubtable source. Lorem Ipsum comes from sections 1.10.32 and 1.10.33 of \
(The Extremes of Good and Evil) by Cicero, written in 45 BC. This book is a treatise on the theory of ethics, very popular during the Renaissance. The first line of Lorem Ipsum, \
, comes from a line in section 1.10.32.
meta_description: External Remote Services. read more at evilsaint.com
meta_keywords: External Remote Services,

name: Active Scanning
description: Active scanning works by sending test traffic into the network and querying individual endpoints.
meta_description: Active scanning works by sending test traffic into the network and querying individual endpoints. read more at evilsaint.com
meta_keywords: Active scanning, test traffic, querying individual endpoints,

name: Discovery
description: Discovery consists of techniques an adversary may use to gain knowledge about the system and internal network. These techniques help adversaries observe the environment and orient themselves before deciding how to act. They also allow adversaries to explore what they can control and what’s around their entry point in order to discover how it could benefit their current objective. Native operating system tools are often used toward this post-compromise information-gathering objective.
meta_description: Discovery consists of techniques an adversary may use to gain knowledge about the system and internal network. These techniques help adversaries observe the environment and orient themselves before deciding how to act.
meta_keywords: Discovery, observe the environment,  orient themselves,

name: Credential Access
description: Credential Access consists of techniques for stealing credentials like account names and passwords. Techniques used to get credentials include keylogging or credential dumping. Using legitimate credentials can give adversaries access to systems, make them harder to detect, and provide the opportunity to create more accounts to help achieve their goals.
meta_description: Credential Access consists of techniques for stealing credentials like account names and passwords. Techniques used to get credentials include keylogging or credential dumping.
meta_keywords: Credential Access, techniques for stealing credentials, Techniques used to get credentials, keylogging,  credential dumping,

name: Persistence
description: Persistence consists of techniques that adversaries use to keep access to systems across restarts, changed credentials, and other interruptions that could cut off their access. Techniques used for persistence include any access, action, or configuration changes that let them maintain their foothold on systems, such as replacing or hijacking legitimate code or adding startup code.
meta_description: Persistence consists of techniques that adversaries use to keep access to systems across restarts, changed credentials, and other interruptions that could cut off their access. Techniques used for persistence include any access, action, or configuration changes that let them maintain their foothold on systems, such as replacing or hijacking legitimate code or adding startup code.
meta_keywords: Persistence, foothold on systems, replacing, hijacking legitimate code,

name: Initial Access
description: Initial Access consists of techniques that use various entry vectors to gain their initial foothold within a network. Techniques used to gain a foothold include targeted spearphishing and exploiting weaknesses on public-facing web servers. Footholds gained through initial access may allow for continued access, like valid accounts and use of external remote services, or may be limited-use due to changing passwords.
meta_description: Initial Access consists of techniques that use various entry vectors to gain their initial foothold within a network. Footholds gained through initial access may allow for continued access, like valid accounts and use of external remote services, or may be limited-use due to changing passwords.
meta_keywords: Initial Access, entry vectors, initial foothold within a network, continued access, external remote services,

name: Reconnaissance
description:
Reconnaissance or Open Source Intelligence (OSINT) gathering is an important first step in penetration testing. A pentester works on gathering as much intelligence on your organization and the potential targets for exploit.

Depending on which type of pentest you agree upon, your penetration tester may have varying degrees of information about your organization or may need to identify critical information on their own to uncover vulnerabilities and entry points in your environment.

Common intelligence gathering techniques include:
* Search engine queries
* Domain name searches/WHOIS lookups
* Social Engineering
* Tax Records
* Internet Footprinting – email addresses, usernames, social networks,
* Internal Footprinting –Ping sweeps, port scanning, reverse DNS, packet sniffing
* Dumpster Diving
* Tailgating
meta_description: Reconnaissance or Open Source Intelligence (OSINT) gathering is an important first step in penetration testing. A pentester works on gathering as much intelligence on your organization and the potential targets for exploit.
meta_keywords: Reconnaissance, Open Source Intelligence, OSINT, important first step in penetration testing, pentester, potential targets for exploit,

name: Programming Languages
description: Programming languages play an important part in the hackers arsenal.
meta_description: Programming languages play an important part in the hackers arsenal.
meta_keywords: Programming languages, hackers arsenal,

name: OpenVPN
description: OpenVPN is an open-source SSL VPN package which can accommodate a wide range of configurations, including remote access, site-to-site VPNs, WiFi security, and enterprise-scale remote access solutions with load balancing, failover, and fine-grained access-controls.
meta_description: OpenVPN is an open-source SSL VPN package which can accommodate a wide range of configurations, including remote access, site-to-site VPNs, WiFi security, and enterprise-scale remote access solutions with load balancing, failover, and fine-grained access-controls.
meta_keywords: OpenVPN, SSL VPN package, remote access, site-to-site VPNs, WiFi security, enterprise-scale remote access solutions, load balancing, failover,  fine grained access controls,

name: Encryption
description: Tools that deal with encryption protocols and purposes
meta_description: Tools that deal with encryption protocols and purposes
meta_keywords: encryption protocols and purposes, encryption protocols,

name: Scapy
description: Scapy is a powerful interactive packet manipulation tool, packet generator, network scanner, network discovery tool, and packet sniffer. Note that Scapy is a very low-level tool—you interact with it using the Python programming language.
meta_description: Scapy is a powerful interactive packet manipulation tool, packet generator, network scanner, network discovery tool, and packet sniffer.
meta_keywords: Scapy, interactive packet manipulation tool, packet generator, network scanner, network discovery tool, packet sniffer,

name: Hping
description: hping is a handy little utility assembles and sends custom ICMP, UDP, or TCP packets and then displays any replies.
meta_description: hping is a handy little utility assembles and sends custom ICMP, UDP, or TCP packets and then displays any replies.
meta_keywords: hping, assembles and sends, ICMP, UDP, TCP packets,

name: Packet Crafting
description: Packet crafting is a technique that allows security consultants to probe firewall rule-sets and find entry points into a targeted system or network.
meta_description: Packet crafting is a technique that allows security consultants to probe firewall rule-sets and find entry points into a targeted system or network.
meta_keywords: Packet crafting,

name: OpenVAS
description: OpenVAS is a vulnerability scanner that was forked from the last free version of Nessus after that tool went proprietary in 2005.
meta_description: OpenVAS is a vulnerability scanner that was forked from the last free version of Nessus after that tool went proprietary in 2005.
meta_keywords: OpenVAS, vulnerability scanner,

name: Unicornscan
description: Unicornscan is an attempt at a User land Distributed TCP/IP stack for information gathering and correlation.
meta_description: Unicornscan is an attempt at a User land Distributed TCP/IP stack for information gathering and correlation.
meta_keywords: Unicornscan, User land Distributed TCP/IP stack, information gathering and correlation,

name: Port Scanners
description: Port Scanners
meta_description: Port scanners. Scan ports. Read more on this category on evilsaint.com
meta_keywords: port scanners,

name: Nessus
description: Nessus is one of the most popular and capable vulnerability scanners.
meta_description: Nessus is one of the most popular and capable vulnerability scanners. read more at evilsaint.com
meta_keywords: Nessus, vulnerability scanners,

name: Vulnerability Scanners
description: Vulnerability scanners are computer programs designed to assess computers, networks or applications for known weaknesses.
meta_description: Vulnerability scanners are computer programs designed to assess computers, networks or applications for known weaknesses.
meta_keywords: Vulnerability scanners, known weaknesses,

name: Web Proxies And Web Scanners
description: A web proxy scanner and web scanners are tools to check vulnerabilities of web servers.
meta_description: A web proxy scanner and web scanners are tools to check vulnerabilities of web servers. read more on this category at evilsaint.com
meta_keywords: web proxy scanner, web scanners, web servers,

name: Command and Control
description: Command and Control consists of techniques that adversaries may use to communicate with systems under their control within a victim network. Adversaries commonly attempt to mimic normal, expected traffic to avoid detection. There are many ways an adversary can establish command and control with various levels of stealth depending on the victim’s network structure and defenses.
meta_description: Command and Control consists of techniques that adversaries may use to communicate with systems under their control within a victim network. Adversaries commonly attempt to mimic normal, expected traffic to avoid detection.
meta_keywords: Command and Control, victim network, avoid detection,

name: Exfiltration
description: Exfiltration consists of techniques that adversaries may use to steal data from your network. Once they’ve collected data, adversaries often package it to avoid detection while removing it. This can include compression and encryption. Techniques for getting data out of a target network typically include transferring it over their command and control channel or an alternate channel and may also include putting size limits on the transmission.
meta_description: Exfiltration consists of techniques that adversaries may use to steal data from your network. Once they’ve collected data, adversaries often package it to avoid detection while removing it. This can include compression and encryption.
meta_keywords: Exfiltration, steal data from your network, compression and encryption,

name: Privilege Escalation
description: Privilege Escalation consists of techniques that adversaries use to gain higher-level permissions on a system or network. Adversaries can often enter and explore a network with unprivileged access but require elevated permissions to follow through on their objectives. Common approaches are to take advantage of system weaknesses, misconfigurations, and vulnerabilities. Examples of elevated access include: • SYSTEM/root level• local administrator• user account with admin-like access • user accounts with access to specific system or perform specific function. These techniques often overlap with Persistence techniques, as OS features that let an adversary persist can execute in an elevated context.
meta_description: Privilege Escalation consists of techniques that adversaries use to gain higher-level permissions on a system or network. Adversaries can often enter and explore a network with unprivileged access but require elevated permissions to follow through on their objectives.
meta_keywords: Privilege Escalation, gain higher-level permissions on a system or network, elevated permissions,

name: THC Hydra
description: When you need to brute force crack a remote authentication service, THC Hydra is often the tool of choice. It can perform rapid dictionary attacks against more than 50 protocols, including telnet, ftp, http, https, smb, several databases, and much more.
meta_description: THC Hydra is often the tool of choice. It can perform rapid dictionary attacks against more than 50 protocols, including telnet, ftp, http, https, smb, several databases, and much more.
meta_keywords: THC Hydra, telnet, ftp, http, https, smb,

name: John the Ripper
description: John the Ripper is a fast password cracker for UNIX/Linux and Mac OS X. Its primary purpose is to detect weak Unix passwords, though it supports hashes for many other platforms as well. There is an official free version, a community-enhanced version (with many contributed patches but not as much quality assurance), and an inexpensive pro version.
meta_description: John the Ripper is a fast password cracker for UNIX/Linux and Mac OS X. Its primary purpose is to detect weak Unix passwords,
meta_keywords: John the Ripper, fast password cracker, UNIX, Linux, Mac OS X,

name: Cracking And Brute-force
description: In cryptanalysis and computer security, password cracking is the process of recovering passwords from data that has been stored in or transmitted by a computer system in scrambled form. A common approach ( brute-force attack) is to repeatedly try guesses for the password and to check them against an available cryptographic hash of the password.
meta_description: cryptanalysis and computer security, password cracking, common approach ( brute-force attack) is to repeatedly try guesses for the password and to check them against an available cryptographic hash of the password.
meta_keywords: brute force attack, cryptographic hash, cryptanalysis, computer security, password cracking,

name: WinDbg
description: WinDbg is a graphical debugger from Microsoft. It is actually just one component of the Debugging Tools for Windows package, which also includes the KD, CDB, and NTSD debuggers. Its claim to fame is debugging memory dumps produced after a crash. It can even debug in kernel mode.
meta_description: WinDbg is a graphical debugger from Microsoft. It is actually just one component of the Debugging Tools for Windows package. includes the KD, CDB, and NTSD debuggers.
meta_keywords: WinDbg, graphical debugger, Microsoft, Debugging Tools for Windows, KD, CDB, and NTSD debuggers,

name: GDB
description: GDB is the GNU Project's debugger. Security folks use it to analyze unknown binaries, by getting disassemblies and stepping through a program instruction by instruction. GDB can debug programs written in Ada, C, C++, Objective-C, Pascal, and other languages.
meta_description: GDB is the GNU Project debugger. Use it to analyze unknown binaries,  disassemblies and stepping through a program. GDB can debug programs in Ada, C, C++, Objective-C, Pascal, and other languages.
meta_keywords: GDB ,GNU, Project debugger, analyze unknown binaries,  Ada, C, C++, Objective-C, Pascal,

name: Immunity Debugger
description: Immunity Debugger is a debugger whose design reflects the need to write exploits, analyze malware, and reverse engineer binary files. It builds on a solid user interface with function graphing, the industry's first heap analysis tool built specifically for heap creation, and a large and well supported Python API for easy extensibility.
meta_description: Immunity Debugger is a debugger whose design reflects the need to write exploits, analyze malware, and reverse engineer binary files. It builds on a solid user interface with function graphing, a large and well supported Python API
meta_keywords: Immunity Debugger, reflects the need to write exploits, analyze malware, reverse engineer binary files, function graphing, Python API,

name: OllyDbg
description: OllyDbg is a 32-bit assembler level analyzing debugger for Microsoft Windows. Emphasis on binary code analysis makes it particularly useful in cases where source is unavailable. OllyDbg features an intuitive user interface, advanced code analysis capable of recognizing procedures, loops, API calls, switches, tables, constants and strings, an ability to attach to a running program, and good multi-thread support. OllyDbg is free to download and use but no source code is provided.
meta_description: OllyDbg is a 32-bit assembler level analyzing debugger for Microsoft Windows. OllyDbg features an intuitive user interface, advanced code analysis, recognizing procedures, loops, API calls, switches, tables, constants and strings, an ability to attach to a running program, and good multi-thread support.
meta_keywords: OllyDbg, 32-bit assembler level analyzing debugger, Microsoft Windows, advanced code analysis, recognizing procedures, loops, API calls, switches, tables, constants and strings,

name: Visual Basic
description: Visual Basic is a third-generation event-driven programming language from Microsoft for its Component Object Model (COM) programming model first released in 1991 and declared legacy during 2008. Microsoft intended Visual Basic to be relatively easy to learn and use.
meta_description: Visual Basic is a third-generation event-driven programming language from Microsoft for its Component Object Model (COM). Microsoft intended Visual Basic to be relatively easy to learn and use.
meta_keywords: Visual Basic, Microsoft, Component Object Model, COM,

name: Python
description: Python is an interpreted, high-level and general-purpose programming language. Python's design philosophy emphasizes code readability with its notable use of significant indentation.
meta_description: Python is an interpreted, high-level and general-purpose programming language. Python's design philosophy emphasizes code readability with its notable use of significant indentation.
meta_keywords: Python,

name: C#
description: C# is a general-purpose, modern and object oriented programming language pronounced as “C Sharp”. It was developed by Microsoft led by Anders Hejlsberg and his team within the .NET initiative and was approved by the European Computer Manufacturers Association (ECMA) and International Standards Organization (ISO).
meta_description: C# is a general-purpose, modern and object oriented programming language pronounced as “C Sharp\

meta_description.name: Ruby
meta_description.description: Ruby is an interpreted, high-level, general-purpose programming language. It was designed and developed in the mid-1990s by Yukihiro \
Matsumoto in Japan. Ruby is dynamically typed and uses garbage collection. It supports multiple programming paradigms, including procedural, object oriented, and functional programming.
meta_description.meta_description: Ruby is an interpreted, high-level, general-purpose programming language. Ruby is dynamically typed and uses garbage collection. It supports multiple programming paradigms, including procedural, object oriented, and functional programming.
meta_description.meta_keywords: Ruby, garbage collection, supports multiple programming paradigms, procedural, object oriented, functional programming.

meta_description.name: IDA Pro
meta_description.description: Disassembly is a big part of security research. It will help you dissect that Microsoft patch to discover the silently fixed bugs they don't tell you about, or more closely examine a server binary to determine why your exploit isn't working. Many debuggers are available, but IDA Pro has become the de-facto standard for the analysis of hostile code and vulnerability research.
meta_description.meta_description: Many debuggers are available, but IDA Pro has become the de-facto standard for the analysis of hostile code and vulnerability research.
meta_description.meta_keywords: IDA Pro, analysis of hostile code, vulnerability research,

meta_description.name: Java
meta_description.description: Java is a class-based, object oriented programming language that is designed to have as few implementation dependencies as possible. It is a general-purpose programming language intended to let application developers write once, run anywhere (WORA), meaning that compiled Java code can run on all platforms that support Java without the need for recompilation.
meta_description.meta_description: Java is a class-based, object oriented programming language. It is a general-purpose programming language intended to let application developers write once, run anywhere (WORA), meaning that compiled Java code can run on all platforms that support Java.
meta_description.meta_keywords: Java, object oriented programming language, write once run anywhere, WORA, Java code,

meta_description.name: PHP
meta_description.description: PHP is a general purpose scripting language especially suited to web development. It was originally created by Danish-Canadian programmer Rasmus Lerdorf in 1994. The PHP reference implementation is now produced by The PHP Group. PHP originally stood for Personal Home Page, but it now stands for the recursive initialism PHP: Hypertext Preprocessor.
meta_description.meta_description: PHP is a general purpose scripting language especially suited to web development. PHP originally stood for Personal Home Page, but it now stands for the recursive initialism PHP: Hypertext Preprocessor.
meta_description.meta_keywords: PHP, general purpose scripting language, Hypertext Preprocessor,

meta_description.name: Debuggers
meta_description.description: A debugger, is a tool for hackers and security consultants which allows them to audit and discover what is being executed within a web app or program
meta_description.meta_description: A debugger, is a tool for hackers and security consultants which allows them to audit and discover what is being executed within a web app or program.
meta_description.meta_keywords: debugger, tool for hackers, security consultants, audit and discover,

meta_description.name: Tor
meta_description.description: Tor is a network of virtual tunnels designed to improve privacy and security on the Internet by routing your requests through a series of intermediate machines.
meta_description.meta_description: Tor is a network of virtual tunnels designed to improve privacy and security on the Internet by routing your requests through a series of intermediate machines.
meta_description.meta_keywords: Tor, virtual tunnels, series of intermediate machines,

meta_description.name: Stunnel
meta_description.description: The stunnel program is designed to work as an SSL encryption wrapper between remote client and local (inetd-startable) or remote servers. It can be used to add SSL functionality to commonly used inetd daemons like POP2, POP3, and IMAP servers without any changes in the programs' code. It will negotiate an SSL connection using the OpenSSL or SSLeay libraries.
meta_description.meta_description: The stunnel program is designed to work as an SSL encryption wrapper between remote client and local (inetd-startable) or remote servers. adds SSL functionality to inetd daemons like POP2, POP3, and IMAP servers without changes in  code. It will negotiate an SSL connection using OpenSSL or SSLeay libraries.
meta_description.meta_keywords: stunnel, SSL encryption wrapper, SSL functionality, inetd daemons, POP2, POP3, IMAP servers,  SSL connection, OpenSSL, SSLeay,

meta_description.name: Socat
meta_description.description: Socat utility similar to the venerable Netcat that works over a number of protocols and through a files, pipes, devices (terminal or modem, etc.), sockets (Unix, IP4, IP6 - raw, UDP, TCP), a client for SOCKS4, proxy CONNECT, or SSL, etc.
meta_description.meta_description: Socat utility similar to the venerable Netcat that works over a number of protocols and through a files, pipes, devices (terminal or modem, etc.), sockets (Unix, IP4, IP6 - raw, UDP, TCP), a client for SOCKS4, proxy CONNECT, or SSL, etc.
meta_description.meta_keywords: Socat, Netcat, pipes, devices, terminal or modem, sockets, Unix, IP4, IP6 - raw, UDP, TCP, client for,  SOCKS4, proxy CONNECT, SSL,

meta_description.name: Netcat
meta_description.description: Netcat is a simple utility reads and writes data across TCP or UDP network connections. It is designed to be a reliable back end tool to use directly or easily drive by other programs and scripts.
meta_description.meta_description: Netcat is a simple utility reads and writes data across TCP or UDP network connections. It is designed to be a reliable back end tool to use directly or easily drive by other programs and scripts.
meta_description.meta_keywords: Netcat, reads and writes data, TCP, UDP, network connections, reliable back end tool,

meta_description.name: Angry IP Scanner
meta_description.description: Angry IP Scanner is a small open source Java application which performs host discovery (\
) and port scans. The old 2.x release was Windows-only, but the new 3.X series runs on Linux, Mac, or Windows as long as Java is installed.
meta_description.meta_description: Angry IP Scanner is a small open source Java application which performs host discovery (\
) and port scans.
meta_description.meta_keywords: Angry IP Scanner, open source Java application, performs host discovery, ping scan, port scans,

meta_description.name: TCPDump
meta_description.description: TCPDump is a command line base packet sniffing tool
meta_description.meta_description: TCPDump is a command line base packet sniffing tool. Read more at evilsaint.com
meta_description.meta_keywords: TCPDump, command line base packet sniffing tool,

meta_description.name: Wireshark
meta_description.description: Wireshark (known as Ethereal until a trademark dispute in Summer 2006) is a fantastic open source multi-platform network protocol analyzer. It allows you to examine data from a live network or from a capture file on disk. You can interactively browse the capture data, delving down into just the level of packet detail you need. Wireshark has several powerful features, including a rich display filter language and the ability to view the reconstructed stream of a TCP session.
meta_description.meta_description: Wireshark is an open source multi-platform network protocol analyzer. examine data from a live network or from a capture file on disk. Interactively browse the capture data, delving down into just the level of packet detail you need. including a rich display filter language, ability to view the reconstructed stream of a TCP session.
meta_description.meta_keywords: Wireshark, multi-platform network protocol analyzer, examine data from a live network, browse the capture data, reconstructed stream of a TCP session,

meta_description.name: Packet Sniffing
meta_description.description: Packet Sniffing is the process of monitoring every packet that is passing through a network. Packet Sniffers will help the network administrators to monitor their network and get the insights on that.\r\n\r\nIt will also help you to detect the root cause of a network issue, troubleshooting network issues, traffic analysis, bandwidth management, and network security & compliance.
meta_description.meta_description: Packet Sniffing is the process of monitoring every packet that is passing through a network. Packet Sniffers will help the network administrators to monitor their network and get the insights on that.
meta_description.meta_keywords: Packet Sniffing, monitoring every packet,

meta_description.name: Impact
meta_description.description: Impact consists of techniques that adversaries use to disrupt availability or compromise integrity by manipulating business and operational processes. Techniques used for impact can include destroying or tampering with data. In some cases, business processes can look fine, but may have been altered to benefit the adversaries’ goals. These techniques might be used by adversaries to follow through on their end goal or to provide cover for a confidentiality breach.
meta_description.meta_description: Impact consists of techniques that adversaries use to disrupt availability or compromise integrity by manipulating business and operational processes. Techniques used for impact can include destroying or tampering with data.
meta_description.meta_keywords: Impact, disrupt availability, compromise integrity, manipulating business, operational processes, destroying or tampering with data,

meta_description.name: Loot Collection
meta_description.description: Loot Collection consists of techniques adversaries may use to gather information and the sources information is collected from that are relevant to following through on the adversary's objectives. Frequently, the next goal after collecting data is to steal (exfiltrate) the data. Common target sources include various drive types, browsers, audio, video, and email. Common collection methods include capturing screenshots and keyboard input.
meta_description.meta_description: Loot Collection consists of techniques adversaries may use to gather information and the sources information is collected from that are relevant to following through on the adversary's objectives. Common loot collection methods include capturing screenshots and keyboard input.
meta_description.meta_keywords: Loot Collection, gather information and the sources information, Common loot collection methods, capturing screenshots, keyboard input,

meta_description.name: Lateral Movement
meta_description.description: Lateral Movement consists of techniques that adversaries use to enter and control remote systems on a network. Following through on their primary objective often requires exploring the network to find their target and subsequently gaining access to it. Reaching their objective often involves pivoting through multiple systems and accounts to gain. Adversaries might install their own remote access tools to accomplish Lateral Movement or use legitimate credentials with native network and operating system tools, which may be stealthier.
meta_description.meta_description: Lateral Movement consists of techniques that adversaries use to enter and control remote systems on a network. Reaching their objective often involves pivoting through multiple systems and accounts to gain. Adversaries might install their own remote access tools to accomplish Lateral Movement or use legitimate credentials with native network and operating
meta_description.meta_keywords: Lateral Movement, pivoting through multiple systems, remote access tools,

meta_description.name: Defense Evasion
meta_description.description: Defense Evasion consists of techniques that adversaries use to avoid detection throughout their compromise. Techniques used for defense evasion include uninstalling/disabling security software or obfuscating/encrypting data and scripts. Adversaries also leverage and abuse trusted processes to hide and masquerade their malware. Other tactics’ techniques are cross-listed here when those techniques include the added benefit of subverting defenses.
meta_description.meta_description: Defense Evasion consists of techniques that adversaries use to avoid detection throughout their compromise. Techniques used for defense evasion include uninstalling/disabling security software or obfuscating/encrypting data and scripts.
meta_description.meta_keywords: Defense Evasion, avoid detection, Techniques used for defense evasion include, uninstalling, disabling, security software,

meta_description.name: Execution
meta_description.description: Execution consists of techniques that result in adversary controlled code running on a local or remote system. Techniques that run malicious code are often paired with techniques from all other tactics to achieve broader goals, like exploring a network or stealing data. For example, an adversary might use a remote access tool to run a PowerShell script that does Remote System Discovery.
meta_description.meta_description: Execution consists of techniques that result in adversary controlled code running on a local or remote system.  exploring a network or stealing data an adversary might use a remote access tool to run a PowerShell script that does Remote System Discovery.
meta_description.meta_keywords: Execution, adversary controlled code, exploring a network, stealing data,

meta_description.name: Resource Development
meta_description.description: Resource Development consists of techniques that involve adversaries creating, purchasing, or compromising/stealing resources that can be used to support targeting. Such resources include infrastructure, accounts, or capabilities. These resources can be leveraged by the adversary to aid in other phases of the adversary lifecycle, such as using purchased domains to support Command and Control, email accounts for phishing as a part of Initial Access, or stealing code signing certificates to help with Defense Evasion
meta_description.meta_description: Resource Development consists of techniques that involve adversaries creating, purchasing, or compromising/stealing resources that can be used to support targeting. Such resources include infrastructure, accounts, or capabilities.
meta_description.meta_keywords: Resource Development, support targeting,

meta_description.name: Juniper
meta_description.description: This section looks at checks to be performed on Juniper Network Devices

meta_description.name: Building Labs and Virtual Machines
meta_description.description: Useful resources and techniques for building labs and virtual machines.
meta_description.meta_description: Useful resources and techniques for building labs and virtual machines.
meta_description.meta_keywords: lab building, building virtual machines
